When kept in an aquarium, using full-spectrum fluorescent lights can help simulate sunlight and encourage healthy growth. Avoid direct sunlight as it can lead to excessive algae growth and potentially harm the plant due to overheating of the water. Balancing light intensity and duration is key to maintaining its vibrant green color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ceratophyllum demersum involves regular thinning rather than traditional cutting, as the plant tends to grow rapidly under optimal conditions. Over time, its dense growth can overcrowd a tank, impacting both aesthetic appeal and water quality. To prune, simply pinch off or cut back the sections that are overgrowing. Removing the older, decaying segments can promote better circulation and light penetration as well as reduce potential ammonia and nitrate buildup from decaying plant matter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"coontail","description":"Ceratophyllum demersum, commonly known as hornwort, rigid hornwort, coontail, or coon's tail, is a species of Ceratophyllum. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10937,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Celtis occidentalis, commonly known as the common hackberry, is generally quite tolerant of different watering conditions once established. Young trees require regular watering to help develop a deep, strong root system. Water thoroughly once a week during the first growing season. Once established, hackberries are drought-tolerant and typically only need supplemental watering in prolonged dry periods. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot, as hackberries do not do well in waterlogged conditions. Always consider local climate conditions and adjust watering frequency accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Celtis occidentalis, or hackberry, thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. It prefers full sun conditions, where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. In shaded areas, the tree may not grow as vigorously and could become more susceptible to disease or poor form. Ensure planting locations provide ample sunlight to support its growth and fruit production. While it can adapt to a range of light conditions, optimal development requires full sun for best results. Consider competitor trees or structures that may cast shade and plan planting accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Celtis occidentalis should be done during its dormant season, typically late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. This helps promote healthy growth and structure. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches, as well as any crossing branches that may cause crowding or stress on the plant. Prune to enhance the tree's natural shape and encourage even spacing of branches. Avoid excessive pruning, as hackberries do not respond well to heavy cuts. Regular light pruning will help maintain a well-balanced and healthy tree."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common hackberry","description":"Celtis occidentalis, commonly known as the common hackberry, is a large deciduous tree native to North America. It is also known as the nettletree, sugarberry, beaverwood, northern hackberry, and American hackberry. It is a moderately long-lived hardwood with a light-colored wood, yellowish gray to light brown with yellow streaks.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["common hackberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Nipple gall","Leaf spot","Hackberry psyllid"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Celtis occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is best to water this plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogged conditions. During the hot, dry summer months, an occasional deep watering can support the plant, especially if signs of wilting are visible. Conversely, in cooler months, little to no supplemental water is typically needed."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia leucophylla thrives in full sun, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate some light shade, insufficient sunlight may result in reduced flowering and leggy growth. It's best to plant this sage in a location that receives ample sunlight, as this will enhance its silvery foliage and vibrant blooms. Full sun also helps in developing the plant's drought-resistant traits, allowing it to thrive in hot and dry conditions typically present in its native habitats."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To maintain the shape and health of Salvia leucophylla, light pruning is recommended in early spring after the threat of frost has passed. Remove any dead, damaged, or overly leggy stems to encourage denser growth and blooming. Cutting back by one-third will generally revitalize the plant and promote a bushier appearance. Avoid heavy pruning late in the season since new growth might not have time to harden off before winter. Regular pruning can also prevent the plant from becoming too woody, which helps in maintaining its aesthetic form."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"purple sage","description":"Salvia leucophylla, the San Luis purple sage, purple sage, or gray sage, is an aromatic sage native to the southern coastal mountain ranges of California and Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Silvery"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Mexico"],"other_name":["purple sage"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Salvia leucophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. In the summer, during active growth, increase watering frequency slightly, while in winter, reduce watering as the plant enters its dormant phase. It's always better to underwater slightly than to overwater, as it is relatively drought-tolerant once established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Teucrium chamaedrys thrives in full sun, ideally receiving at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. For best performance, choose a well-lit location sheltered from harsh winds, which will protect the plant while providing the sunlight it needs to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Teucrium chamaedrys is important for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushy growth. Trim the plant in early spring before new growth begins, cutting back last year's stems to about half their length. A more significant trim in late summer after flowering can help maintain a neat appearance and prepare it for winter."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wall germander","description":"Teucrium chamaedrys, the wall germander, is a species of ornamental plant native to Mediterranean region of Europe and North Africa, and to the Middle East as far east as Iran. In its natural habitat, this plant often grows in shady or rocky areas with good drainage, so replicating these conditions will help it thrive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aquilegia canadensis thrives in partial shade to full sun, though it performs best in areas with morning sun and afternoon shade. Ideally, provide 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimum flowering and growth. In hotter climates, providing a bit of afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching and keep the plant looking its best."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Aquilegia canadensis, light pruning is beneficial to encourage healthy growth and more blooms. After the flowering season, which usually spans from late spring to early summer, remove spent flowers to prevent self-seeding and direct the plant's energy back into the foliage and roots. Cut back old or damaged foliage in early spring to allow for new growth. If the plant becomes too leggy, prune it back to maintain a more compact shape. Regular deadheading will also keep the plant looking tidy and can encourage a second flush of blooms."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"red columbine","description":"Aquilegia canadensis (Canadian or Canada columbine, eastern red columbine, wild columbine) is an herbaceous perennial native to woodland and rocky slopes in eastern North America, prized for its red and yellow flowers. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent overheating, but generally, an abundance of sunlight will promote better blooming. Best performed in late summer after flowering, trim back the plant by removing spent flowers and cutting the stems back by about one-third. It’s vital to avoid cutting into woody stems as they do not regenerate new growth effectively. Regular light pruning throughout the growing season, by deadheading spent blooms, can enhance the plant’s appearance and promote continuous flowering. Keep the plant tidy by also removing any dead or diseased branches when noticed."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"topped lavender","description":"Lavandula stoechas, the Spanish lavender or topped lavender, is a species of flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae, occurring naturally in Mediterranean countries.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["topped lavender"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lavandula stoechas"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In shaded conditions, care should be taken to monitor for any signs of stress and adjust the environment as necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Alnus glutinosa is generally done to maintain shape, remove dead or diseased wood, or control size. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Regularly check for branches that cross or rub against each other, as these can be cut to prevent damage. It is recommended to prune only as needed and to make clean cuts to avoid infection. Alnus glutinosa does not typically require heavy pruning, as it has a naturally irregular form often best left to develop its own shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European Alder","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["European Alder"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Alnus glutinosa"],"soil":["Wet","Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11725,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anacamptis morio, commonly known as the Green-winged Orchid, requires moderate watering. During its growing season in spring and early summer, keep the soil slightly moist but not soggy. Reduce watering in the dormant season during late summer and autumn. Monitor the plant to ensure the soil never dries out completely, and always water lightly, allowing the top layer of soil to dry between watering sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anacamptis morio prefers partial to full sunlight conditions. The plant flourishes in areas that receive at least 4 to 6 hours of full sunlight per day, ideally in the morning, with some shade during the hotter afternoon hours to prevent the soil from drying out too quickly. In cooler climates, more direct sunlight is beneficial, while in warmer areas, providing a bit more shade can prevent leaf scorch. Indoor care should mimic these conditions by placing the plant near a bright window where it can receive sufficient sunlight without being directly exposed all day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not generally necessary for Anacamptis morio, but deadheading spent blooms encourages better growth and prevents the plant from expending energy on seed production. To deadhead, gently snip off the flower stems after they have finished blooming but before the seed pods form. For maintaining the plant’s health, remove any dead, damaged, or yellowing leaves throughout the growing season. Pruning should be minimal to mimic the plant's natural growth cycle, promoting vigorous growth and more abundant blooming the following year."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"green-winged orchid","description":"Anacamptis morio, the green-winged orchid or green-veined orchid (synonym Orchis morio), is a flowering plant of the orchid family, Orchidaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10423,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ficus benjamina, commonly known as the weeping fig, requires regular watering but appreciates a dry period between waterings. It is crucial to let the top couple of inches of soil dry out completely before watering again to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season (spring and summer), water more frequently. In contrast, reduce the watering during the fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing. Always ensure that the pot in which your Ficus is planted has drainage holes to allow excess water to escape, thereby preventing water from stagnating at the bottom."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus benjamina thrives best in bright, indirect sunlight. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the morning, too much direct sun can scorch the leaves. If the plant is indoors, a spot near a window with filtered light is ideal. In situations where adequate natural sunlight isn't available, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights. Be cautious about moving the plant frequently, as this can lead to leaf drop due to stress. If possible, try to maintain consistent light conditions to keep the plant healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus benjamina is essential to encourage healthy growth and maintain its shape. It is best to prune in the spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to allow for better air circulation and light penetration. This also prevents the spread of disease. Regular light pruning throughout the growing season can help maintain the desired size and shape of the plant. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, and avoid cutting too close to the main stem. After pruning, avoid moving the plant to reduce stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Weeping fig","description":"Ficus benjamina, commonly known as weeping fig, benjamin fig or Ficus tree, and often sold in stores as just ficus, is a species of flowering plant in the family Moraceae, native to Asia and Australia. It is the official tree of Bangkok. The species is also naturalized in the West Indies and in the States of Florida and Arizona in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South and Southeast Asia","Australia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["Weeping fig"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Cutting","Air Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ficus benjamina"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with particularly hot summers, some light afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect it from intense heat, but overall, a bright, sunny exposure is ideal to meet its light needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Lessingia germanorum is not typically necessary as the plant maintains a tidy growth habit. If pruning is desired to maintain shape or to remove dead or diseased parts, the best time is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Gently trim back stems to their base or shape lightly to encourage a more bushy growth pattern. Avoid cutting back more than one-third of the plant at a time to prevent stress. Regular removal of spent flowers can promote longer blooming periods and maintain overall plant health."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"San Francisco lessingia","description":"Lessingia germanorum is a rare species of flowering plant in the daisy family known by the common name San Francisco lessingia. It is a state and federally listed endangered species. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10825,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fagus sylvatica, commonly known as European beech, typically thrives in regions with good rainfall, and thus benefits from consistent moisture. While young beech trees require regular watering to establish a strong root system, mature trees are more drought-resistant. During dry spells, ensure the soil stays moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to root rot. It's important to provide deep watering, allowing the water to reach the roots, especially during the tree's growing season from spring to early fall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fagus sylvatica grows best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the tree should receive at least four to six hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate some shade, optimal growth occurs with more sunlight, promoting denser foliage and a fuller appearance. If planted in a shaded area, ensure that it still has enough light to maintain its lush green leaves and overall vigor. The tree's ability to adapt to different light conditions makes it versatile, but for the best results, aim for a sunnier location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Fagus sylvatica should generally occur during its dormancy period, from late autumn to early spring. This helps maintain the tree's shape and removes any dead or damaged branches. Beech trees form a dense canopy, so thinning cuts can improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, reducing the risk of disease. Avoid removing too many large branches in one go to prevent shock, and focus on selective pruning to enhance the tree's natural structure and health. Tools should be sharp and clean to make precise, clean cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European beech","description":"Fagus sylvatica, the European beech or common beech, is a deciduous tree belonging to the beech family Fagaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["European beech"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Beech Leaf Disease"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Fagus sylvatica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10627,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum carolinense, commonly known as horse nettle, prefers to grow in well-drained soils and does not require frequent watering once established. In general, aim to water horse nettle only when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum carolinense thrives in full sunlight conditions, though it can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It naturally grows in open areas such as fields, roadsides, and prairies, where it gets plenty of sunshine. If planted in a garden, ensure it is situated in a spot that does not receive excessive shade from larger plants or buildings. Providing ample sunlight helps in maintaining its structural integrity and encourages healthy flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solanum carolinense is generally not necessary for its health, but can be beneficial for controlling its growth and preventing it from becoming too invasive. If desired, prune the plant in early spring or late winter before new growth begins. Cut back any dead or damaged stems, and remove flowers if you wish to prevent seed dispersal and self-seeding. Using gloves for protection is advisable due to this plant’s spiny nature. Regular monitoring and removal of unwanted growth can help manage its spreading tendencies effectively."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Carolina horsenettle","description":"Solanum carolinense, the Carolina horsenettle, is not a true nettle, but a member of the Solanaceae, or nightshade family. It has also been found in parts of Europe, Asia, and Australia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10628,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cichorium intybus, also known as common chicory, prefers well-draining soil to prevent waterlogging. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings. This plant is relatively drought-tolerant once established and can suffer from root rot if overwatered. During hot, dry spells, increase watering frequency slightly to prevent the leaves from wilting. Reduce watering in cooler, wetter months to match the plant’s reduced growth rate. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cichorium intybus thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. It can tolerate partial shade but may exhibit slower growth and reduced flowering under such conditions. Place the plant in a sunny, open location with good air circulation to avoid fungal diseases that can occur in too humid or shaded environments. When grown indoors, south-facing windows can provide adequate light, or you may supplement with grow lights to ensure the plant receives enough light intensity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cichorium intybus is not typically necessary for plant health, but it can be done to manage shape and promote bushier growth. During the growing season, you may pinch back the stems to encourage branching and reduce legginess. Additionally, removing dead or yellowing leaves and spent flowers regularly will help maintain a neat appearance and prevent disease. If grown for its roots or flowers, consider cutting the plant back in late fall to stimulate new growth in the following spring season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"chicory","description":"Common chicory (Cichorium intybus) is a somewhat woody, perennial herbaceous plant of the dandelion family Asteraceae, usually with bright blue flowers, rarely white or pink. Many varieties are cultivated for salad leaves, chicons (blanched buds), or roots (var. sativum), which are baked, ground, and used as a coffee substitute and food additive. In the 21st century, inulin, an extract from chicory root, has been used in food manufacturing as a sweetener and source of dietary fiber.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","West Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["chicory"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Cichorium intybus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Cut back old stems to about 6-12 inches above the ground. Pruning also helps to control the plant's spreading habit, as it can become invasive if not well maintained."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coulter's matilija poppy","description":"Romneya coulteri, the Coulter's Matilija poppy or California tree poppy, is a perennial species of flowering plant in the poppy family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10426,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dicentra formosa, commonly known as the Pacific bleeding heart, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in spring. However, it is essential to avoid waterlogging, as this can cause root rot. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil remains damp to the touch but not soggy. Reduce watering during the summer months when the plant may go dormant, making sure that the soil never completely dries out. In areas with dry climates, additional watering might be required to maintain adequate moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dicentra formosa thrives best in partial to full shade, replicating its native forest floor habitat. It prefers morning sunlight or dappled shade throughout the day and can tolerate full shade but might produce fewer blooms in very low light conditions. If planted in sunnier spots, ensure that ample moisture is provided to offset higher light exposure and potential heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dicentra formosa involves removing spent flowers and any unattractive, yellowing, or damaged foliage to promote healthier growth and extend its blooming season. After the plant has finished blooming, cut back the flower stalks to encourage more blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. In late fall, once the foliage begins to die back naturally, trim it down to ground level to prepare the plant for winter dormancy. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11227,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phacelia grandiflora, commonly known as large-flowered phacelia, prefers a moderate watering schedule. During its growing season in spring and early summer, ensure the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch, allowing excess water to drain away. Reduce the frequency of watering during its dormant period in fall and winter. These plants have some drought tolerance but may not flower well if consistently under-watered. It's important to avoid letting them completely dry out or sit in water-saturated soil, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phacelia grandiflora thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, provide at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate light shade, but too much shade can result in fewer blooms and weaker growth. If grown in hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can protect it from the intense midday sun. When choosing a planting location, consider placing it in an area that receives morning sunlight followed by afternoon shade to balance its needs. The right amount of sunlight will help this plant produce vibrant flowers and maintain its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phacelia grandiflora is usually not necessary beyond deadheading spent flowers to promote a longer blooming period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. After the blooms have faded, you can trim the flower stalks back to the plant's base. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, a light trim can encourage more compact growth. Removing any dead or damaged foliage will also maintain the plant's health. It's best to perform any necessary pruning during the active growing season. Remember to sterilize pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Large-flowered Phacelia","description":"Phacelia grandiflora is a species of phacelia known by the common name largeflower phacelia. It is native to the coastal hills and southern Transverse Ranges of southern California and Baja California, where it grows in coastal sage scrub, chaparral, and other local habitat, including areas recently burned by wildfire.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["Large-flowered Phacelia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Phacelia grandiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers well-drained soil that mimics its natural habitat. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. It's best to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Typically, watering once a week during its growing season, from late winter to early summer, is sufficient. During its dormant period in late summer and fall, reduce watering to allow the plant to naturally rest, only giving enough water to prevent the soil from completely drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Orchis anthropophora thrives in partial to full sun, depending on the climate. However, in hotter climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to prevent the leaves from scorching. Ideally, it should receive around 6 hours of sunlight each day. If grown indoors or in a less sunny spot, supplemental light might be necessary to ensure proper growth and flowering. Ensure the plant receives plenty of natural light during its active growth phase for optimal results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Orchis anthropophora is minimal and generally involves removing any dead or yellowing leaves to keep the plant healthy and tidy. This can be done throughout the growing season as needed. After the flowering period, old flower spikes will naturally die back and can be trimmed close to the base. It’s important to use sterile cutting tools to prevent the spread of diseases. Avoid excessive pruning, as leaving the foliage intact helps the plant store energy for the next flowering cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Man Orchid","description":"Orchis anthropophora, the man orchid (formerly Aceras anthropophorum), is a European species of orchid whose flowers resemble a human figure. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10828,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sorbus americana, commonly known as the American mountain ash, prefers consistently moist, well-drained soil. It's important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during dry spells, as it does not tolerate prolonged dry conditions. However, avoid over-watering, which can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply and less frequently to encourage deep root development. During the growing season, ensure that the soil is not allowed to dry out completely between waterings, but reduce the frequency in fall and winter."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sorbus americana thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and berry production. While it can tolerate some shade, growth may be slower and berry yield may be reduced. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help to prevent leaf scorch and reduce stress on the tree. Ensure the location has good airflow to prevent fungal diseases associated with higher humidity and low light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Sorbus americana, pruning is generally not needed unless you want to shape the tree or remove dead, diseased, or crossing branches. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Prune to maintain an open canopy, which promotes good air circulation and reduces the risk of disease. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree. Regularly check for suckers at the base and remove them to encourage a single trunk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American mountain ash","description":"The tree species Sorbus americana is commonly known as the American mountain-ash. It is a deciduous perennial tree, native to eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American mountain ash"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust","Fireblight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Sorbus americana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12028,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Romneya trichocalyx, commonly known as the Matilija poppy, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires careful watering to thrive. It prefers well-draining soil and once established, it needs minimal watering, typically every two to three weeks. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other diseases. During the first growing season, water more frequently to help establish the root system, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. In arid climates or periods of extreme heat, increase watering slightly to support blooming."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Romneya trichocalyx thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth and flowering. It is best suited to sunny locations where it can soak in the rays all day long. Partial shade conditions may result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. Ensure it's planted in a spot that receives ample sunlight throughout the day, especially in cooler or more temperate climates, to encourage vibrant blooms and robust growth. This sun-loving plant needs ample light to maintain its stunning floral display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Romneya trichocalyx is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. It is best pruned in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems from the plant, cutting them back to the ground as needed. This plant can spread aggressively via underground rhizomes, so regular pruning helps control its spread. Additionally, cutting back the stems after flowering can help promote a more compact growth habit and ensure better blooming the following year."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hairy Matilija Poppy","description":"Romneya trichocalyx, the bristly Matilija poppy or hairy Matilija poppy, is a species of flowering plant in the poppy family. This poppy is native to San Diego, Ventura, and Santa Barbara counties in California, as well as Baja California, Mexico, where it grows in dry canyons in chaparral and coastal sage scrub plant communities. Like its relative Romneya coulteri, it is used as an ornamental plant, kept for its large, showy flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Northern Mexico"],"other_name":["Hairy Matilija Poppy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Root cuttings"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Romneya trichocalyx"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10226,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Allium cepa, commonly known as the onion, requires consistent moisture throughout its growing season to develop properly. However, it is crucial to avoid waterlogging the soil since overly wet conditions can lead to bulb rot and other fungal issues. Ideally, onions should be watered once or twice a week, depending on the weather and soil conditions, ensuring that the top few inches of soil remain moist. As the bulbs begin to mature, you can gradually reduce the watering to promote drier conditions, which helps the bulbs cure and prevents splitting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium cepa thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Onions develop better in bright light, which helps ensure they produce large and healthy bulbs. Insufficient sunlight can lead to smaller and less flavorful onions, so it's essential to plant them in a location that receives steady sunlight throughout the day. If you are growing them in partial shade, ensure that the shade does not exceed a couple of hours daily to avoid stunted growth and poor yield."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Onions typically do not require traditional pruning to thrive. However, it is important to remove any flower stalks that emerge to direct the plant's energy towards bulb development. If you notice any yellowing, damaged, or diseased leaves, these should be trimmed back to maintain plant health and reduce pest issues. When harvesting onions, the stalks should be bent over to facilitate curing, which can be considered a form of pruning. This practice helps prevent the onions from focusing on further top growth, thus allowing the bulbs to mature properly. "}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Onion","description":"The onion (Allium cepa L., from Latin cepa \"onion\"), also known as the bulb onion or common onion, is a vegetable and is the most widely cultivated species of the genus Allium. It thrives in moist, well-drained soil. When watering, ensure the soil is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the peak of summer or in dry spells, additional watering may be necessary to compensate for the lack of rain. However, avoid letting the plant sit in standing water, as this can harm the roots. Once the plant is established, it becomes more drought-tolerant but still benefits from occasional watering in prolonged dry conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus succulentus thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. When planting this species, choose a location that receives abundant sunlight, ideally in the morning, to ensure vigorous growth. In extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent stress during peak heat periods. Ensure the site is open and sunlit to support the plant's vibrant flower production and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus succulentus typically involves deadheading spent flowers to promote prolonged blooming and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively if this is undesired. Cut back flower stalks once the blooms have faded to encourage new growth and tidy the plant's appearance. At the end of the growing season, you can cut back the entire plant to its base if it becomes too leggy or unsightly. Prune any damaged or diseased foliage as needed to maintain overall plant health. Since this is an annual plant, extensive pruning is usually not necessary."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"arroyo lupine","description":"Lupinus succulentus is a species of lupine known by the common names hollowleaf annual lupine, arroyo lupine, and succulent lupine.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Arizona"],"other_name":["arroyo lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus succulentus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning since this can reduce flowering and fruiting potential. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11729,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ophrys tenthredinifera, commonly known as the wasp orchid, is a terrestrial orchid that prefers moderate watering. During its growing season in the fall through spring, it requires regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's important to use well-draining soil to prevent root rot, especially if it's planted in a pot. During the summer dormancy period, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough moisture to prevent the bulbs from drying out completely. Water less frequently during rainy periods and ensure the pot or garden location has good drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ophrys tenthredinifera thrives in full sun to partial shade. It naturally grows in open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes in the Mediterranean regions, so it is adapted to plenty of sunlight. However, in garden settings, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat, especially in warmer climates. When grown indoors or in regions with less sunlight, ensure that the plant receives at least 6 hours of bright, indirect light per day to replicate its natural conditions and promote healthy growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not generally necessary for Ophrys tenthredinifera, as it is a perennial orchid that naturally senesces after flowering. After the flowering period, the plant's stalks and foliage will die back naturally during the summer dormancy. It is best to leave the foliage and flower stems until they have completely died back and become brittle, as they provide nutrients to the bulbs. Once they are dry, they can be gently removed. This approach prevents any risk to the plant's health and ensures nutrient recycling back into the bulb for the next growth season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sawfly Orchid","description":"Ophrys tenthredinifera, the sawfly orchid, is a terrestrial species of orchid native to the Mediterranean region from Portugal and Morocco to Turkey. During its growing season, from spring to early summer, it should be watered regularly to keep the soil moist but not waterlogged. This means watering deeply about once a week, allowing the water to reach the roots without pooling. As the plant matures, it becomes more drought-resistant and can tolerate less frequent watering. However, during dry spells or extremely hot weather, additional watering may be necessary to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asparagus officinalis thrives in full sun, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. Plant it in an area that receives ample sunlight to promote vigorous growth and a high yield of spears. While asparagus can tolerate some partial shade, such conditions can result in slower growth and thinner spears. Therefore, choosing a sunny spot in your garden is crucial for an abundant harvest. In hotter climates, providing a small amount of afternoon shade can help prevent stress during intense heat while still allowing the plant to receive enough light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Asparagus officinalis is primarily focused on maintaining the health and productivity of the plant. In the fall, once the foliage (or fronds) turns yellow and dies back, cut the stems down to the soil level. This prevents pest infestations and disease over the winter. In the early spring, before new shoots appear, remove any remaining debris to provide a clean environment for new growth. Throughout the growing season, removing any weak, damaged, or diseased stems can help encourage healthy growth and prevent the spread of issues. Be gentle to avoid disturbing the roots."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wild asparagus","description":"Asparagus, or garden asparagus, folk name sparrow grass, scientific name Asparagus officinalis, is a spring vegetable, a flowering perennial plant species in the genus Asparagus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["wild asparagus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Asparagus beetle","Fusarium rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Crown","Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Asparagus officinalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10830,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Citrus maxima, or pomelo, requires regular watering to thrive, especially during dry periods. It's important to maintain a consistent moisture level in the soil, avoiding both drought and waterlogging. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. In hotter climates, more frequent watering may be necessary, whereas in cooler seasons or climates, reduce the frequency to prevent root rot. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. Always use well-draining soil to prevent water stagnation around the roots which can lead to fungal problems."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Citrus maxima thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce healthy fruit. It prefers sunny, warm climates and should be planted in a location where it receives plenty of light throughout the day. If growing indoors or in a less sunny environment, consider supplementing with grow lights to ensure the plant receives sufficient light exposure. In areas with intense midday sun, providing some light afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. Consistent sunlight is key for vigorous growth and optimal fruit development in Citrus maxima."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Citrus maxima requires removing dead or diseased wood and maintaining a manageable shape and size. This should be done after the fruiting season but before the spring growth spurt. Thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Also, remove any suckers that grow from the base of the tree, as they can sap energy from the main plant. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid disease transmission, making sure each cut is clean and at a slight angle. Proper pruning encourages healthy growth and helps increase fruit production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pomelo","description":"The pomelo, Citrus maxima, or Citrus grandis, also called pomello, pummelo, pommelo, pamplemousse, jabong (Hawaii), or shaddock, is a natural (non-hybrid) citrus fruit, similar in appearance to a large grapefruit, native to South and Southeast Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Winter","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["Pomelo"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider Mites","Fruit Flies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Citrus maxima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12030,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oxalis debilis prefers consistently moist but well-draining soil. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Be careful not to overwater, as this can cause root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering as the plant enters a dormant phase and requires less moisture. Ensure excess water can drain away easily, preventing waterlogging of the soil which can be detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oxalis debilis thrives best in partial shade but can tolerate full sun for part of the day, particularly in climates that are not excessively hot. If placed in a very sunny location, ensure the plant receives some protection during the hottest part of the day to avoid leaf scorch. Indoors, place the plant near a north or east-facing window where it can receive bright, indirect sunlight. Adjust positioning if the plant starts to show signs of light deficiency or excess."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oxalis debilis is minimal and mostly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage healthy growth. Pinch or cut off any spent blooms to promote new flowering and prevent the plant from self-seeding. Regularly check for any signs of disease or pest infestation and remove affected parts promptly. Pruning can be done throughout the growing season as needed to control the plant's shape and size."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Largeflower pink-sorrel","description":"Oxalis debilis, the large-flowered pink-sorrel or pink woodsorrel, is a perennial plant and herb in the Oxalidaceae family. Its original distribution is South America but has become a very cosmopolitan species, occurring in all continents except Antarctica. It can be found in both temperate and tropical areas.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Largeflower pink-sorrel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Oxalis debilis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11730,"attracts":["Bees","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ophrys bombyliflora, commonly known as the bumblebee orchid, requires well-draining soil and moderate watering. It is important not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. During its active growing season, which is typically in the spring, water the plant sparingly, just enough to keep the soil moist but not wet. Reduce watering significantly after the flowering period and during dormant months in summer, only watering enough to prevent the soil from drying out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ophrys bombyliflora thrives in environments that mimic the Mediterranean climate, which includes exposure to full sun to partial shade. Ideally, this orchid should receive bright but indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially during the midday hours, can be too intense and might scorch the plant, so it’s best to provide filtered sunlight or a location that offers a mix of sun and shade. Throughout the growing season, ensure it gets enough light to promote healthy blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ophrys bombyliflora is a minimal requirement. After the plant has finished its flowering cycle, it's critical to remove any withered flowers or stems to encourage healthy growth in the following season. These plants naturally wither and shed their leaves after their growing season, so there's no need for extensive pruning. It's best to leave them as they are during the dormancy period. Be gentle when handling this orchid, as they are delicate and sensitive to damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bumble Bee Orchid","description":"Ophrys bombyliflora, the bumblebee orchid, is a species of Ophrys (bee orchid), native from the Mediterranean region from Portugal and the Canary Islands to Turkey and Lebanon. The genus name <i title=\"Greek language text\">Ophrys is from the Greek in reference to the hairy lips of the flowers of this genus; the specific epithet <i title=\"Latin language text\">bombyliflora is from the Greek bombylios (bumblebee) in reference to the appearance of the flowers of this species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean Basin"],"other_name":["Bumble Bee Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Ophrys bombyliflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Calcareous","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11133,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tamarix ramosissima, commonly known as the saltcedar, requires moderate watering. It is quite drought-tolerant once established but grows best when the soil retains some moisture. Water young trees regularly to help establish root systems, especially during prolonged dry periods. As the plants mature, reduce watering frequency but aim to keep the soil mildly moist. Avoid waterlogged soils as this can cause root rot. Ensure good drainage to prevent standing water around the base. In general, focus on deep, infrequent watering to encourage deep root growth, providing sufficient moisture during the hottest months for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tamarix ramosissima prefers full sun to thrive and produce its signature feathery flowers, ideally requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade but flowering will be significantly reduced. Plant it in an open location to ensure maximum sun exposure. When placed in too much shade, the plant might become leggy, with sparse foliage and fewer blossoms. If grown indoors or in a container, position it in a south-facing window or use a grow light to supplement its sunlight needs. Providing ample sunlight enhances its growth and flowering capabilities."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tamarix ramosissima is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to encourage new growth and airflow. Thin out crowded areas to prevent internal branches from becoming too dense, which can lead to disease. Cut back overgrown branches to maintain desired size and shape, ensuring cuts are made just above a bud or branch junction. Regular pruning prevents the plant from becoming too woody and encourages lush blooms in the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"saltcedar","description":"Tamarix ramosissima, commonly known as saltcedar or salt cedar, is a deciduous arching shrub with reddish stems, feathery, pale green foliage, and characteristic small pink flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Mongolia","Russia"],"other_name":["saltcedar"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tamarix ramosissima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11531,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stachys albens, also known as white hedge-nettle, requires moderate watering to thrive. It is essential to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, as overwatering can lead to root rot. During the warmer months, ensure the plant receives enough water to prevent the soil from drying out completely. In contrast, during colder months, reduce watering frequency, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. It's beneficial to water in the morning, which allows excess moisture to evaporate throughout the day and reduces the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stachys albens thrives best in environments where it can receive full to partial sunlight. Ideally, it should be placed in a location where it can enjoy at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. However, it can also tolerate partial shade, especially in areas with exceedingly hot summer sun, where afternoon shade would be beneficial. When grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window, but be cautious of intense midday sun through glass, which can scorch the leaves. Ensuring the right balance of light will promote vigorous growth and healthy foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stachys albens helps maintain its shape and promotes healthier growth. The best time to prune is in early spring or after the plant has finished blooming. Begin by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased stems to improve air circulation and prevent the spread of disease. You can also trim back long stems to encourage bushier growth. If the plant becomes too dense, thinning out some inner branches can help light penetrate through. Regular removal of spent flowers can also extend the blooming period. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"whitestem hedgenettle","description":"Stachys albens, also known as whitestem hedgenettle or white hedgenettle, is a mint endemic to California. S. albens flowers have a 2-lipped, 5-lobed calyx, which is densely cob-webby and white to pinkish in color with purplish veins. The plant is fuzzy all over, with opposite, triangular, serrate leaves, a square stem, a layered spike of many small flowers, and a minty smell if bruised.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Mexico"],"other_name":["whitestem hedgenettle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Stachys albens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10429,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calochortus eurycarpus, commonly known as the widefruit mariposa lily, prefers moderately dry conditions. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. During the growing season, which is typically in spring, provide sufficient moisture to encourage vibrant blooms, but avoid waterlogging the soil. As the plant enters dormancy in the late summer or fall, reduce watering substantially to mimic its natural dry conditions. Excessive watering during dormancy can lead to bulb rot, so it's important to keep the soil relatively dry unlike during its growth period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus eurycarpus thrives best in full sunlight, making exposure to at least 6 hours of direct sunlight ideal for its growth and flowering. This plant is adapted to open grasslands and meadows, requiring lots of light to produce its distinctive, showy blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, the bloom production might not be as prolific as when it is grown under full sun. Ensure the plant is situated in a spot where it receives morning light and some afternoon protection if the climate is extremely hot, to avoid overheating."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Calochortus eurycarpus is minimal and primarily involves the removal of spent flowers and foliage. After the blooming period, spent flowers can be deadheaded to promote cleanliness and prevent potential seed formation if not desired. Allow the foliage to naturally yellow and die back, which typically happens by late summer. This process helps store energy in the bulb for the next growing season, so avoid trimming the leaves too early. Once the leaves have completely withered, they can be neatly trimmed away at the base."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white mariposa lily","description":"Calochortus eurycarpus (white mariposa lily) is a North American species of flowering plant in the lily family. It is native to the western United States: Montana, Idaho, eastern Oregon, western Wyoming, northeastern Nevada (Box Elder County) and southeastern Washington (Asotin County + Garfield County).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western United States"],"other_name":["white mariposa lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Calochortus eurycarpus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Keeping the substrate slightly damp is important, but ensure there is proper ventilation to prevent mold. Mist the growing area if it appears to dry out but avoid water accumulation to prevent rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Craterellus cornucopioides is a fungus and does not require sunlight for photosynthesis like plants do. Instead, this mushroom prefers shaded and sheltered environments. When cultivating, mimic its natural habitat by providing indirect light or low light conditions, typically found under forest canopies. Direct sunlight can dry out the growing medium and harm the fungal growth, so it's best to keep them in a cool, damp, and shaded area. Keeping temperatures moderate will also aid in healthy growth and fruiting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't applicable to Craterellus cornucopioides as it is a fungus, not a plant. If you are cultivating this mushroom, \"pruning\" would be analogous to carefully harvesting the mature fungi without damaging the mycelium network. Use a knife to cut the mushroom at the base when it reaches the desired size. This helps encourage further flushes of growth and maintains the health of the fungal network. Regularly remove any decayed or damaged fungi to ensure healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Horn-of-plenty","description":"Craterellus cornucopioides, or horn of plenty, is an edible mushroom. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Regular deadheading, or removing faded flowers, can prolong the blooming period and prevent the plant from self-seeding too aggressively. It's important to avoid overwatering; misting once every week or two should suffice, depending on the ambient humidity and temperature conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vulpicida canadensis prefers partially shaded environments, common to its natural habitats like boreal and temperate forests where it often thrives on tree trunks or rocky substrates. Direct, intense sunlight should be avoided as it can desiccate the lichen, leading to damage. Ideally, this lichen should receive filtered or indirect sunlight, mimicking dappled light typically found under a forest canopy. Achieving a balance that allows moderate light exposure will help it photosynthesize effectively without risk of overheating."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not generally necessary for Vulpicida canadensis, as lichens grow and regenerate in natural, irregular patterns. Most interventions are related to grooming rather than pruning, involving the careful removal of any dead or decaying material. This should be done gently, usually with tweezers, to avoid damaging the delicate structure of the lichen. Occasionally, older parts or debris may need to be removed to keep the lichen clean and healthy, supporting its continued growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brown-eyed Sunshine Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Brown-eyed Sunshine Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vulpicida canadensis"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10530,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":"[{\"type\":\"watering\",\"description\":\"Ipomopsis aggregata, commonly known as Scarlet Gilia or Skyrocket, prefers dry to moderately moist soil conditions. It is drought-tolerant, making it suitable for xeric gardens. Water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot as this plant thrives in well-drained conditions. During its establishment phase, more frequent watering may be necessary to help root growth, but once established, little irrigation is needed beyond normal rainfall.\"},{\"type\":\"sunlight\",\"description\":\"This plant thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. In its natural habitat, it grows in open areas with plenty of light, which supports its vibrant blooms. While it can tolerate some partial shade, too much shade will result in fewer blooms and leggier growth. Cut back to the point of healthy wood and thin out the canopy to allow sunlight penetration. Be cautious not to over-prune as this can stress the tree. Excessive moisture can lead to bulb rot, so ensure that the plant is never sitting in water and the soil is well-drained. During active growth in the spring, regular watering can support lush foliage, but it's less necessary during the dormant period in summer and fall. Adjust watering based on local climate and rainfall, avoiding soggy conditions while keeping the plant healthy and thriving."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium amplectens thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This ensures healthy growth and encourages the best flowering results. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, reduced light might lead to fewer blooms and less robust growth. Select a planting location with unobstructed sunlight exposure, such as an open garden bed or a sunny border. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window to provide adequate light, supplementing with grow lights if necessary to mimic natural sunlight conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Allium amplectens, pruning is minimal. After the blooming period in late spring, remove spent flower stalks to prevent unwanted self-seeding and to maintain a tidy appearance. This also encourages the plant to direct energy back into the bulb for next year's growth. Trim any yellow or dead foliage as it appears, which typically occurs after flowering. Avoid cutting green foliage as it plays a critical role in photosynthesis and bulb nourishment. In the fall, once the plant dies back naturally, you can tidy up by cutting back any remaining withered leaves."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"narrowleaf onion","description":"Allium amplectens is a species of wild onion known by the common name narrowleaf onion. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11731,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ophrys lutea, a type of orchid, generally requires minimal watering, particularly because it is native to regions with a Mediterranean climate, where drought conditions are common. Watering should mimic its natural environment: prefer infrequent, light watering over frequent soaking. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, especially during its dormant phase in the summer. Overwatering can lead to rot due to poor drainage, so ensure the orchid is potted in a mix that allows fast drainage, such as a bark-based orchid mix. Adapt your watering to its growth cycle, increasing during the active growing period in spring."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ophrys lutea prefers a location where it can receive plenty of indirect sunlight, as it is native to the bright but not scorching conditions of Mediterranean climates. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, should be avoided to prevent leaf burn. Providing bright, filtered light or partial shade will encourage optimal growth and flowering. During active growth in spring, position it to allow morning sunlight with some shade in the hotter afternoon. Outdoors, dappled sunlight through a tree canopy is ideal. Always monitor for signs of excessive sunlight, such as scorched leaves, and adjust accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ophrys lutea primarily involves removing spent flower spikes and dead foliage. Once the orchid has finished flowering, cut back the flower spike at its base to encourage the plant to conserve energy for further growth. Leaf trimming is generally unnecessary unless leaves are diseased or dying, in which case they should be removed to prevent disease spread. Pruning should be done with sterilized tools to avoid introducing any pathogens to the plant. This orchid generally does not require extensive pruning as they are adapted to somewhat self-manage their growth cycle naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow Bee-orchid","description":"Ophrys lutea, the yellow bee-orchid, is a species of orchid native to southern Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East, the range extending from Portugal and Morocco to Syria.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean","North Africa","Southern Europe"],"other_name":["Yellow Bee-orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Ophrys lutea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Calcareous","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10832,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tuckermannopsis orbata, commonly known as a type of foliose lichen, typically requires minimal direct watering in natural environments, as it usually absorbs moisture from the air. Avoid direct watering as it can easily lead to deterioration; instead, simulate its natural habitat by occasionally misting lightly with distilled or rainwater. Ensure the environment is well-ventilated to prevent water from sitting on the surface, which can encourage mold or rot. Monitor humidity and adjust as necessary to maintain an optimal moisture level reflective of its natural settings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tuckermannopsis orbata thrives in shaded environments with indirect sunlight, typical of its natural habitat on rocks or trees under canopy cover. Direct sunlight can be harmful, causing the lichen to dry out. If kept indoors or in a terrarium, place it in an area where it receives diffused light for a few hours a day. Avoid putting it in locations with intense sunlight exposure, like south-facing windows, unless filtered through sheer curtains. It is vital to mimic the dappled light conditions it adapts to naturally, ensuring a balance between light and shade to maintain its health and vibrancy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tuckermannopsis orbata is generally not required due to its low-growth, non-invasive nature. However, if you're growing it as part of a lichen garden or in a terrarium, you may wish to control its spread or remove any damaged or decayed sections. Use sterilized tools to gently trim away any unwanted or dead parts. This should be done with care to not disturb the main body, as lichen is sensitive to disruption. Regularly check for any signs of disease or infections, which might necessitate additional pruning, and ensure overall cleanliness of its environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"variable wrinkle-lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["variable wrinkle-lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Tuckermannopsis orbata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When watering, aim for the base of the plant to avoid getting water on the leaves, which can sometimes lead to disease. The plant is somewhat drought-tolerant once established, but it thrives best with regular watering, especially in the growth season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Maianthemum racemosum thrives in partial to full shade, making it an ideal choice for woodland gardens or shaded borders. It prefers dappled sunlight or morning sun with protection from the harsh afternoon rays. In regions with very mild, cool summers, it might tolerate more sun if soil moisture is retained conscientiously. However, too much direct sunlight can stress the plant, leading to scorched leaves and poor growth. Providing the plant with a shady, cool environment replicates its natural woodland habitat and fosters its best health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Maianthemum racemosum is generally minimal. However, you can remove dead or damaged leaves throughout the growing season to encourage healthy growth and maintain a tidy appearance. After the plant has finished flowering and the berries have formed, you may cut back the stems in fall or wait until early spring before new growth appears. This helps to tidy the plant and manage its shape. Avoid heavy pruning as it can reduce the plant's ability to photosynthesize effectively."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Solomon's plume","description":"Maianthemum racemosum (treacleberry, feathery false lily of the valley, false Solomon's seal, Solomon's plume or false spikenard; syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11134,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tamarix aphylla, or the Athel tree, is highly drought-tolerant once established and typically requires very little watering. It thrives in dry conditions, and excessive moisture can lead to root rot, particularly if the soil does not drain well. Water young trees regularly until they are established to encourage deep root growth. After establishment, limit watering to very dry periods, maybe once every 10-14 days if there has been no rainfall. Ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings to mimic its natural arid environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tamarix aphylla requires full sun for optimal growth, ideally receiving at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It thrives in bright, open areas and can tolerate the high light levels of arid and semi-arid environments. Although it is quite adaptable to different light conditions, providing ample sunlight will ensure the healthiest growth and the best flowering. In shaded conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, so placing it in a sunny spot is crucial for its vigor and overall appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tamarix aphylla is essential to maintain its shape and encourage the growth of healthier branches. It is best to prune during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent them from affecting healthy parts of the tree. Additionally, thin out dense areas to improve air flow and light penetration. Avoid heavy pruning all at once; instead, aim for gradual shaping over several seasons to prevent stress on the tree. This will also help in controlling its size and preventing invasiveness."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"athel tamarisk","description":"Tamarix aphylla is the largest known species of Tamarix (height: to 18 metres–60 ft). The species has a variety of common names, including Athel tamarisk, Athel tree, Athel pine, and saltcedar. It is an evergreen tree, native across North, East and Central Africa, through the Middle East, and into parts of Western and Southern Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Africa","Asia","Middle East"],"other_name":["athel tamarisk"],"pest_susceptibility":["Stem borer insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Tamarix aphylla"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Adjust watering frequency depending on the climate, providing more during hot, dry conditions and less during cooler or rainy periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Penstemon newberryi thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. In areas with harsh sun, a bit of afternoon shade can help prevent scorching while still providing ample light for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Penstemon newberryi involves removing spent flower spikes to encourage new blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. After the flowering period, cut back stems by about one-third to promote bushier growth. In the winter or early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to prepare for the new growing season. Be careful to avoid cutting into the plant’s woody base. Regular pruning not only helps in maintaining plant vigor but also enhances its natural shape and flower production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Pride","description":"Penstemon newberryi is a species of penstemon known by the common name mountain pride. It is native to the mountains of northern California, Oregon, and Nevada, where it grows in rocky habitat, often at high elevation, such as talus. It is a bushy, mat-forming subshrub growing up to 30 centimeters tall. The leaves are mostly basal on the plant, oblong or oval and toothed, measuring 1 to 4 centimeters in length, with a few smaller pairs...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Mountain Pride"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Penstemon newberryi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant deeply, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12032,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Orobanche hederae does not require traditional watering since it is a parasitic plant that derives moisture and nutrients from its host plant rather than from soil or other sources. To cultivate it, ensure the host plant (often Hedera helix, or the common ivy) is well-established and properly watered. Aim to keep the host at an appropriate moisture level, as this will indirectly provide the water needs for Orobanche hederae. Avoid overwatering the host plant to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Orobanche hederae thrives best when its host plant is growing in conditions suitable for Hedera helix, which usually entails partial shade to full shade environments. Direct sunlight is not ideal, especially since fully sunlit conditions can harm the host plant, subsequently affecting the parasitic Orobanche hederae. It's also a good idea to cut back plants heavily in late winter or early spring before new growth starts, as this will promote vigorous growth and a tidy appearance.
